The unexpected response of the crystal structure on pressure treatment is observed above 7.5 GPa. While the b and c axes continue to decrease, the a-axis reveals an anomalous increase upon compression indicating a change in the compression mechanism (Fig. 2, Supplementary Fig. 1). Indeed half of the TO 4 units start to undergo pressure-induced geometrical distortion. The progressive deviation of P1O 4 and Be2O 4 tetrahedra from the ideal tetrahedral geometry above ~7.5 GPa is perfectly visible on plots showing quadratic elongation and bond angular variance parameters as a function of pressure
27 (Supplementary Fig. 2). Such a distortion results from the closure of eight-membered rings and progressive approach of the fifth oxygen to the P1 and Be2 atoms across the rings (Supplementary Fig. 3).
